General question: why did we introduce the IPV4 and IPV6 resolvers? We should have already had DNS resolver at that time, I guess?

---

Reviewed 29 of 31 files at r1.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, all discussions resolved, some commit checks failed.

---

*[doc/naming.md, line 28 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324#-LCGrAPGC7FJ1G9L7j_S:-LCGrAPGC7FJ1G9L7j_T:b-pfdj5d) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/c7574a126471459f9fbb3fe3f9cbe2909d6777f5/doc/naming.md#L28)):*
> ```Markdown
> 
> - `dns:[//authority/]host[:port]` -- DNS (default)
>   - `host` is the host to resolve via DNS.
> ```

Does this mean the URI "path" is `host` without `port`?

---

*[doc/naming.md, line 29 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324#-LCGrHo50yW1rwWvUU9f:-LCGrHo50yW1rwWvUU9g:bn1d8fb) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/c7574a126471459f9fbb3fe3f9cbe2909d6777f5/doc/naming.md#L29)):*
> ```Markdown
> - `dns:[//authority/]host[:port]` -- DNS (default)
>   - `host` is the host to resolve via DNS.
>   - `port` is the port to return for each address.  If not specified,
> ```

If the returned value is either what we input or the default (443), why do we need this component? Does this component affect how the host is resolved? If not, can we defer attaching the port until when we receive the resolved IPs?

Or do we just want to hand off this per-address work to the resolver so that it's easier on our side?

---

*[test/core/end2end/dualstack_socket_test.cc, line 130 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324#-LCGvX6rAL1eARiAhZvp:-LCGvX6s3jsfGx20LEUb:bh791a6) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/c7574a126471459f9fbb3fe3f9cbe2909d6777f5/test/core/end2end/dualstack_socket_test.cc#L130)):*
> ```
> response_generator
> ```

What will be broken if this is moved into the scope of `if (client_host[0] == 'i')`?

---

*[test/cpp/end2end/round_robin_end2end_test.cc, line 1 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324#-LCGkOmw6EBf_XluDTuv:-LCGkOmw6EBf_XluDTuw:b-m4jp6x) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/47537f51acad4aa1e6d5ce75441680f66b500ea7/test/cpp/end2end/round_robin_end2end_test.cc#L1)):*

<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 4 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[doc/naming.md, line 28 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324#-LCGrAPGC7FJ1G9L7j_S:-LDxN4EIAnICTIa9aVpY:bk630ys) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/c7574a126471459f9fbb3fe3f9cbe2909d6777f5/doc/naming.md#L28)):*
Previously, AspirinSJL (Juanli Shen) wrote…
Does this mean the URI "path" is `host` without `port`?
No. As per RFC-3986, the path is actually everything after the authority (i.e., technically, it includes the `/` before `host`). But the syntax here is not showing how to break it up into components of the URI; it's showing the logical pieces relative to this specific scheme. --- *[doc/naming.md, line 29 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324#-LCGrHo50yW1rwWvUU9f:-LDxNKYk4bEdHeU3tl31:b-vmba75) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/c7574a126471459f9fbb3fe3f9cbe2909d6777f5/doc/naming.md#L29)):*
Previously, AspirinSJL (Juanli Shen) wrote…
If the returned value is either what we input or the default (443), why do we need this component? Does this component affect how the host is resolved? If not, can we defer attaching the port until when we receive the resolved IPs? Or do we just want to hand off this per-address work to the resolver so that it's easier on our side?
It's true that the DNS resolver does not return port information, but there are other resolvers that do. In order to support both of those models, our design is that the resolver API is responsible for returning the port information. In cases like the DNS resolver, it returns the value specified by the user, or assumes a default if nothing is specified. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15324)*
I know of at least one case where a user is using the IP resolvers (see #12569), so I guess we'll have to keep them.
